p: 11. An appearance-3 can become an appearance-2, a mere semblance. A rash is indeed a genuine phenomenon (appearance-1) insofar as it shows up as a rash. But as a symptom (appearance-3) a rash can “privatively” become a mere semblance or specious appearance if it indicates something other than what actually causes the rash, thereby depriving the symptom of its true meaning. Say, for example, a young man blushes out of embarrassment. If we were to take the redness of his cheeks not as a manifestation of embarrassment but as the symptom of an underlying fever, the red cheeks in that case would be a mere semblance.
